title: The role of photorespiration during the evolution of C<sub>4</sub> photosynthesis in the genus <italic>Flaveria</italic>
abstract: C<sub>4</sub> photosynthesis represents a most remarkable case of convergent evolution of a complex trait, which includes the reprogramming of the expression patterns of thousands of genes. Anatomical, physiological, and phylogenetic and analyses as well as computational modeling indicate that the establishment of a photorespiratory carbon pump (termed C<sub>2</sub> photosynthesis) is a prerequisite for the evolution of C<sub>4</sub>. However, a mechanistic model explaining the tight connection between the evolution of C<sub>4</sub> and C<sub>2</sub> photosynthesis is currently lacking. Here we address this question through comparative transcriptomic and biochemical analyses of closely related C<sub>3</sub>, C<sub>3</sub>–C<sub>4</sub>, and C<sub>4</sub> species, combined with Flux Balance Analysis constrained through a mechanistic model of carbon fixation. We show that C<sub>2</sub> photosynthesis creates a misbalance in nitrogen metabolism between bundle sheath and mesophyll cells. Rebalancing nitrogen metabolism requires anaplerotic reactions that resemble at least parts of a basic C<sub>4</sub> cycle. Our findings thus show how C<sub>2</sub> photosynthesis represents a pre-adaptation for the C<sub>4</sub> system, where the evolution of the C<sub>2</sub> system establishes important C<sub>4</sub> components as a side effect.
